Description: Scarab carved from stone, said to be limestone in register, but more likely steatite; well-shaped back with major features such as prothorax and elytra respectively marked by single and double incised lines; head and clypeus well indicated; underside incised with vertically arranged motif representing central sign, likely an obelisk, flanked by monkeys raising their arms, above neb-basket sign and below boat of Amun with sun-disc; longitudinally pierced; scarce remains of blue-green glaze.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Baboons in a worshipping attitude, flanking an obelisk is a design that was popular during the New Kingdom. See a parallel dated to the 19th dynasty: Keel 2010, 258-9, no 538. The weird shape of the obelisk and the badly formed hieroglyph representing the sacred barge of the sun god Ra could be an indication that this scarab is a later copy. Keel, O. 2010, Corpus der Stempelsiegel-Amulette aus Palästina/Israel : von den Anfängen bis zur Perserzeit, Orbis biblicus et orientalis, Series Archaeologica 31, Fribourg.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.44) (phase 3)
